Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: The grandmother learns that a family member is dealing with a significant personal crisis.
Expectation2: Show love and kindness to others, following the teachings of Jesus
Situation2: They notice someone in their circle going through difficulties and respond with care
Story:
I sat at my kitchen table, the phone heavy in my hand. My daughter had just confided in me about her struggles—her marriage was falling apart, and she begged me not to tell anyone else in the family. As a grandmother, I felt the weight of keeping our family close, of making sure everyone was connected and supported. But now, I was being asked to keep a secret, to hold back from reaching out to my other children and grandchildren, who might be able to help or at least offer comfort.

At the same time, my faith tugged at me. At church, we’d just talked about loving our neighbors, about reaching out to those in pain, no matter who they were. I knew a woman from our congregation who was also struggling, and I’d been quick to offer her a listening ear and a warm meal. Why did it feel so much harder with my own family? I wanted to show love and kindness, to be the grandmother who held everyone together, but I was torn between honoring my daughter’s trust and the urge to rally the family around her. My heart ached as I wrestled with what to do next.
